description.text: A Fluent Case for a VAWT.
Just a simple bracket to hold the common flip-type power switch.

Print a bracket (if you want it for other side - don't forget to mirror it).
Print one or two of Circuitboard_bracket_m3_diag standard Mendel part: http://reprap.org/wiki/File:Circuitboard_bracket_m3_diag.png
I decided to use it because I already had some spare parts. Take a switch (I took mine from my broken table lamp), put it into a hole and glue it. I used the glue gun to do this. Hang the bracket on the sloped threaded rod (see picture).
Fix the bracket using the Circuitboard_bracket, M3 bolts, washers and nuts.
If you want to hold the power cable (I recommend to do so), put another one Circuitboard_bracket on the front side and squeeze the cable between brackets. Tighten the bolts. Connect power cables to the switch. Enjoy.

title: Ultra Thin HTC Evo 4G LTE Fitted Case

description.text:
I finally did it! After spending many hours measuring and building, I finally made a case that is super thin and fits perfectly to my phone! No more square edges, no more bulk. I have printed this and it fits perfectly to the phone! I will upload pictures ASAP! Note: I did not make a hole for the kickstand, I will upload a version with it later but who really uses the kickstand more than just to show people you have one. UPDATE: I made a version with a hole for the kickstand! You're welcome! Also Poetic is based off of the Poetic Atmosphere for the HTC One. Poetic will look the best in clear with an added rubber coating on the outer offset edge. For rubber I recommend http://www.homedepot.com/p/Performix-Brand-11-oz-Plasti-Dip-Black-Rubber-Coating-Spray-11203-6/100131010#
Should Look Great! I'm trying it myself ATM and will update you guys with the look!

author: Turkey2Spartan

description.text:
I had made this rack for my spools with regular PVC fittings but got sick and tired of having to disassemble every time I needed to swap out a spool or rearrange them behind the printer.

These fittings allow the pipe to rest on top and you can simply lift up the pipe to re-load or rearrange your spools.

Depending on how good your printer is at bridging, you won't even need supports!

My xyz Da Vinci 1.0A is NOT very good at bridging, but still managed to turn out a usable model.

description.text:
Light and sturdy carriage for ANET A8 converted to bowden E3D extruder.
You can select of variety clamps with fan mount and round 8mm,12mm, 17mm cubic inductive sensors or without a sensor or just a bare clamp for setups with fan(s) attached to E3D hot end directly. It looks awesome if printed of a temperature dependent color changing filament.

check out my other stuff for ANET A8 and enjoy!.

Fitting:
It uses original setup - bolts and nuts to attach X- belt, but positioned slightly higher to make the belt run linearly. It has 6 attachment points for zip ties. The clamp is attached with two M3 bolts and M3 nuts fitted in carriage slots for tight fit.

Print setup:
clamps - print upside down, 50-100% infill 1,2mm walls, no supports
carriage - 50% infill, 1.2mm walls no supports
nozzle - print solid, with supports touching buildplate only
material - preferably ABS, but PLA works fine for carriage too for open setup.

Calibration:
in configuration.h:
define X_MAX_POS 220
define X_MIN_POS -16
define Y_MAX_POS 220
define Y_MIN_POS -9
define Z_MAX_POS 240
define Z_MIN_POS 0

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 30 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle], for TSD E3D V5 carriage
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

define ABL_GRID_MAX_POINTS_X 4

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 205
define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 205

versions:
clamp Bl touch - !prototype! please test and comment
clamps v6h and v6j - prototype for "ANET" blue cubic Z sensor
fan nozzle 5h - optimized high flow nozzle
clamps v6e and v6f - for 17x17mm cubic sender like tronxy or prefered TL-Q5MC1(works great at 5V ~4mm sensing distance). v6e is attached by two M3x25mm bolts, v6f is fixed by a zip tie. calibration X +30mm (right) of the nozzle.
clamp v6d - !prototype! for 12mm inductive sensor, calibration X +30mm (right) of the nozzle
clamp v5b no fan - optimized bare hot end without a bracket for a fan
nozzle v5 - high flow nozzle
clamp v5 - optimized clamp for 8mm inductive sensor, calibration X +30mm (right) of the nozzle

note: Please leave a feedback and proposals in comments.

comments.text: Hi mate, thanks for your feedback. I was also considering re-positioning of the probe to a colder area since the cubic type ( orange) gives me inconsistent measurements.. The round type probes seem to be better temperature compensated (tested 8mm, 12mm) . I have a bad experience with tensioners mounted at the back of the carriage. Most of them are weak and without mods of Z idler they tend to bent vertical rods. A much better option are tensioners located at the right Z idler. I can recommend https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1428253 idler with modified inserts https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2271909, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2271158. I'm also going to design a belt clamp for carriage. No cdw files, It's designed in Sketchup :(
comments.author: WombatBA

comments.text: No problem. I will load into TinkerCad and see what I can come up with. For the belt tensioner, you are correct I use something on the right side of the Z axis. I use https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2016779 for the back of the carriage and drilled a few holes in the back of the plate that I printed and it worked great. I want to just incorporate it directly into the plate as well as move the bottom mounting holes down a bit to handle the gap correctly. The plate itself caused the two horizontal rods to get pulled together and bind the entire setup. Also, I have changed over to igus solid polymer blocks and there is no longer any room for movement on the vertical plane. They are fantastic when they are allowed to move freely. I will let you know what I come up with. Thanks

description.text:
A water drip nozzle made to fit the barbed adapter I made recently.

The part got 0.3mm clearance for the adapter.
In the design the hole on the nozzle is 0.9mm in diameter, though it's probably smaller than that after printing.

This is pretty much a permanent when added due to the short clearance, so be sure to make it go through the same steps as on the original adapter to make it waterproof and it might help to glue the two parts together. After you push it into the adapter it's hard to remove again, push it as far as possible, the adapter got a small notch that can catch the nozzle.

If you try it, please tell me how it works. I haven't actually worked with drip irrigation before now so any feedback would be nice.

Update 27/04/2017 Added the stl file for the barbed connector so people don't forget to do both.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

10

Notes:

Be sure to level your bed properly as it is a pretty tight fit

comments.text: I just did a test print and then setup a trial setup to see how quickly water came out.  For my purposes, its far too fast, a steady stream. I had to put a couple kinks in the hose to get it down to a steady drip.  Now I did have a drop of a couple of feet so I had a bit of back pressure going on, but that's about what my final setup will have.

I did some small edits to the original nerf scope by MartijnRoozendaal (linked as the remixed item), to be easier to print, and better fit my Nerf Longstrike CS-6 specifically. I printed the pieces specifically in this orientation, so they would be strong enough to survive the wear and tear of being put on and removed from the toy. To make the prints come together into one object, I solvent weld them together using acetone as this was an ABS print, but left the knobs "free" so they still maintain "functionality" of rotating around the central axis. Be careful when inserting the knobs into the central piece, as the stress caused by the pins could be enough to split your print in half though.

title: CR 10 fan duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Better working fan duct for the CR10.

I had some issues with the first few layers (compare the benchys). So I tried to set up a different fan duct. Unfortunately the other existing duct on thingiverse for a stock printer configuration didnt fit my printer, as I seem to have a different part cooling fan.

So I made this one myself, with a shocking difference. The first layers are much better now. No blobbing or what so ever.

Compare your cooling fan with the shown one and it should fit yours.

title: Power supply mounting brackets for Mendel

description.text: Modified design of front bracket for Mendel.

• Print a PowerSupplyBracket_Back from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20482
  • Print 2 different (left/right) front brackets from this design.
  • Screw front brackets to the PSU using short M3 bolts. Do it only for bottom holes, not for the top ones. Otherwise it is impossible to attach the bracket.

  • Screw the upper M3 bolts.
  • Screw the back brackets using M3 bolts and some washers.

description.text:
This is a lovely Keychain i designed in solidworks for my girlfriend who is a huge Disney Fan. This is a very simple straight forward print. Fits on my Monoprice Select mini and printed in just about an hour given my settings. I use a resolution of .1 but could probably go as low at .25 and i am sure it will still come out looking good. I did use a raft but that's solely my preference given the fact that it gives me a really good finish on the bottom surface. There is no hole in the top i simply drill one in after and loop a keychain through it. I will add one in and update it later.Thanks for checking out my work.

Update 6/5/2017: I have added two two designs that come with a place to loop a keyring onto. One is a bar located in between the ears for a more centered hanging keychain, while the other is a small loop on the outer left ear for a slanted hanging look. Supports is recommended for the ear loop sense it is not just bridging a gap but cantilevered out in space. Thanks again for looking and downloading.

Monoprice Select Mini

comments.text:
I think its moisture in your filament, iT explodes in your nozzle while printing and leaves a hole in your print.
Try to dry your filament, for example in the oven and store iT in a bag with Some silica.

It happens when the initial part and final part of the outer layers connect
i've coasting off, printing at 1300 mm/min at outer layers... dunno what to do more to be honest

comments.text: 2nd the coasting... If no, then maybe....your printing too fast. then.. Look at calibrating your flow rate. do the 100mm Extrude test.

comments.text: Have you looked at retraction settings being more than extrusion? you may be retracting 2mm on layer change but then not extruding enough  to start the next layer.

comments.text:

It happens when the initial part and final part of the outer layers connect
comments.author: Olliedog12000

comments.text: Does this happen on layer change? If it happens randomly, it is probably your extruder missing steps. Step missing could be caused by incorrect extruder stepper current, blunt extruder gear, the filament not being pressed hard enough into the extruder gear etc.

description.text:
Yes, this is the craze of 2016 and the craze of 2017 combined in one beautiful nonsense. :)

EDIT(2017.04.28.): Worked a bit on the fitting and added a 4mm wider body too.
EDIT(2017.05.03.):STEP files added, if you need to adjust the fitting.

You will need:
-A precise printer (preferably 3D)
-608 bearing (whatever type you prefer)
-three M8 nuts
-superglue

Instrucions:
After printing all the parts (the hemispheres WITH support) just insert the nuts, the bearing and the bearing caps. They should friction fit nicely. Glue the hemispheres to the body with superglue.

Happy spinning! :)

*Leaning back and waiting for 'I choose you!' comments.

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2089058

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=2089058

Using the following options:

Lenght = 205
Name = TR LEGER GRADUATION 2017

This funky candle holder, or small sculpture, was designed in Project Shapeshifter (Autodesk). Squares are the primary geometry and spinning around the Z-axis is the primary motion. One end is closed to form a thin, solid base. This is my 2nd full design using Shapeshifter but my 1st one [f3d-1] came out better. I rushed this one and made mistakes. Dimensions: 130mm H, 125mm W (top); 60mm W (bottom); and 30mm W at narrowest point, which is ~20mm above the build plate. Note: You must pay special attention to the wall thickness. If you print with thin walls and/or low quality, a fatal structural weakness gets exposed at the thinnest section. (2 shells on Normal was too weak for me).

It is important to focus on the narrowest section about 20mm off the build plate because this joint can fail. In fact, it did fail on my only attempt at print this at full scale. I believe the failure was caused by using low resolution settings (2 shells, 0.30 mm layer height) and also by lower-quality filament (it was not the worst filament I've seen but still not great). Avoiding this failure could be as simple as using better filament. But I think using higher resolution settings would get you a solid object. You can always scale it down to 1:4 or smaller, tweak the shells and layer thickness until you get a solid piece. I do not recommend lighting a candle in this holder because: 1) the base is insufficient and will easily tip, and 2) the holder lacks any inner support structure that would hold a candle. Tweaking the Design: Shapeshifter has a great export feature that prompts you for units and file type (.stl or .obj). Unfortunately it does not currently have the ability to Open Previous or Import design files. You can use the parameters shown in the screen shot to recreate the design and then tweak it. If you're still reading, the good news is that printing the thing is easy:
  • download .stl and import into MakerWare or similar
  • scale it to the size you want (see notes below on scale)
  • print
  • enjoy!
    • If any of you are successful in tweaking the design starting with the .stl, please let me know what software you used to make the changes. Thanks!

description.text:
Version 2 Deli card. This has the start time and the end time in hour format with am and Pm noted. This is more obvious as to which hour the card applies to. The older version one is here and has only the start time in 2400 hr format :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2251638

The electric vehicle owners at the company where I work have figured out over several years, how to fairly share the charging stations at the company. Due to the large number of EVs wanting to charge, and the limited stations, each car is limited to 2 hours. This "deli card" system was worked out over time so that everyone can fairly share and can maximize the use of the charge stations. The laminated paper deli cards don't last very long, so I made these smaller plastic cards. There is one for each hour from 0500 to 2000. They fit into a shirt pocket, and have a hole for hanging on a wire at the charge station. I'm going to work on making a 2 layer version that does not need the support rods and could be printed on a 2 color 2 head printer.

How the "deli card" system works at my work place.

  1. Its ad-hoc, so when you arrive at work in the morning, you grab 2 cards for the 2 hours you want to charge. Example 1000 and 1100
  2. There are 2 parking spots for each charge station. By having 2 parking spots for each charge station, the charge station is in continuous use, without having to have each car owner be there exactly at the hand-off time.This is works very good for public and work charging locations
  3. You pull in at your starting charge time (example 1000) and unplug the car charging, and plug your car in.
  4. The car that was previously charging has an hour to move their car and make space for the next car. They return their cards to the hook or bin at the charge station.
  5. At (this example) 1200 the next car will pull in and move the charge cord from your car to their car.
    Number 4 repeats : You have an hour (1200-1300) to move your car and make space for the next car. You return the (example 1000 and 1100) deli cards to the hook or bin at the charge station.
  6. And so on, this repeats all day long, and starts over on the next day.

This set is public in Tinkercad, so you can customize them for your charge stations.
How to modify: 1. make a duplicate copy. 2. rename it. 3. tinker it. 4. Click the card, un-group 5. click on the 4 support rods for the B the 4 and move them up and off the object, 6. Click the card and un-group. 7. click on the B3-4 and edit it to say what what you want to match your local charge station. 8. Make copies, and move the support rods into place for letters/numbers with centers (like A, B, D, O, P, Q R, 4, 6, 8, 9, 0) 9. click on the text and the hole and the card and GROUP. 9. Click on the support rods and the card and GROUP. 10 exit, move on to the next hour card and repeat.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hvlv5LOsjYi

author: bkgray115

description.text: Electric Field and Flux lab demo.

Electric Flux We have a physics lab where students use a loop over lines of electric flux, and record the number of lines as a function of normal vector angle of the loop area. Plotting these, they discover the flux Phi = A B cos(theta). Previously we used sticks in styrofoam and a pipecleaner loop. I thought I'd try to make something a bit nicer. This is about 10x10x13, and takes about 180 m of filament for the main thing. I suggest printing the 'loop' using a different color for contrast.
See Tutorials in Introductory Physics by McDermott et al (Dept Physics, U Washington), p. 77 "Electric Field and Flux"

The Idea of this kind of LiPo guard is from Dinochio.
I saw this and had the idea to make one for my 3" Realacc X130.

Thanks to Dino for this great Idea!

title: Mic Stand Raspberry Pi Holder - Horizontal
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
nigeljohnson73 made a great timelapse harness, but it only worked with the Raspberry Pi Camera Module version 1, so I made a version that worked with the RPi Camera Module v2.1

Then, I decided that I wanted to try and secure his timelapse harness to something. I have a few mic stands kicking around, so I made an adapter that converts the mic stand (5/8"-27) to the harness (M16x2.0 metric).

I realized that the keyholes in the back of my case were off-center on one axis, so mounting it vertically looked ugly. See previous thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2270041

So I said "This is really something brand-new. It just works with the pre-existing harness." Not calling this a remix at this point going forward. It does, however, work really well with the harness by nigeljohnson73 so go check it out. The system is awesome!

This is basically a horizontal Raspberry Pi holder that connects to the standard US mic stand. As you can see by the pictures, when used with the harness, this is a complete set from holding the camera steady at the appropriate angle, to cable management, all the way down to holding the RPi closer to the camera. I went out and bought a 24" ribbon cable, but I imagine with this set-up, you could have one even shorter!

If you're using a caseless RPi, don't forget to see the cage nigeljohnson73 made!

(If you decide to buy the awesome C4Labs case pictured, don't forget to tell them I sent you, even though I won't get anything - it's just nice to know I'm sending business their way. It's a cool company! This one has a really nice fan!)

https://www.amazon.com/Zebra-Virtue-Black-Raspberry-C4Labs/dp/B01F1O0Q8U

I believe the next, alternate version of this will have the holes either 6mm square (probably ideal), or running the other way (vertically versus horizontally). With the keyholes in my case, I had to run the zip-strip in such a way that it didn't mesh up perfectly with the holes' orientation. That's okay. Next version soon....

Also, as with any of my ideas/designs, please let me know if you'd like an alternate version. I can't always say I'm going to have the time, but it's good to have the ideas out there!

I may actually get to printing a Baby Groot planter eventually!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Glass bed with PVA glue, and a rock-solid leveling is the best way to print. The stronger springs that came with my glass bed make it so much easier to keep things level, even after multiple prints and multiple days!

Been printing with PLA more, recently, due to the reduced odor, toxicity, and lower temperatures. Seems more forgiving?

This guy really should be printed so that the back with the holes is flat on the bed, obviously. Unless you feel like printing it in some other orientation. I'm sure on its side would work?

Printing these so the threads are "upright" makes for some schmutz in the threads, but as long as it's not really bad, you can just use the metal threads of the mic stand to clean that out. Worked well for me!

Fusion 360, Netfabb 2017 and Simplify3D

My sixth item I've designed, and I'm going to call this my first "from scratch" item, versus a remix. I created a new "back-plate" that runs the entire length symmetrically and horizontally, adjusted the size, added a grid of evenly-spaced holes on the back (for zip strips or twist ties or whatever your thing is), plus three additional holes in the base for pass-through. Added the same fillets for consistency, plus who doesn't like roundness? I decided not to fillet certain parts of this, just in case you get into a knife fight, and you need to cut someone with the corners. Or if you're stuck on a desserted island, and you can only eat your pie and cake with this adapter. You're welcome.

Thanks again to nigeljohnson73 for the exceptional timelapse harness design!

title: Ossum Jeep Tub for small Printers

description.text:
Edited the largest piece of Ossum's Jeep, (the tub) for smaller printers. I'm making several variations till I find out what works best. I have a LEFT/RIGHT side with a few variations, as well as working on a 4 part design that fits on a 120 cubed print area like the monoprice mini. I tried to keep consistent so the same screw sizes should fit throughout.
I did my best to maintain the original design as much as possible with just adding or cutting pieces away in a fashion that it should fit back together.

NOTE:This will need to be printed with supports.

I printed any of these designs yet to check for clearance around the transmission area, please notify me if you print it yourself and see an issue/solution!

4/28/17: I added an alternative for the L/R version which includes a better screw hole position (and area you could glue) Reminder that I have not checked for clerance around transmission so there's a good chance this current version won't fit without some dremel/trimming. I'll correct it when I get a chance to test fit it.

I also added a quick 4 piece design for printers with a 120x120x120 print area like the stock monoprice mini. Once again, have not tested the fit around the transmission yet.

description.text:
Foreword: On April 2017, I received an e-mail asking for a customized adapter that would allow a gamer to play The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild using only the right hand. However, the person who requested it didn't provide me with any feedback after the first prototype was finished. So, I started testing it on my own and discovered that, although it worked properly, its use would be uncomfortable for a lot of users. Due to its size and shape, only gamers with big hands and/or long fingers could use it comfortably. For that reason, I strongly encourage you to try out my other two adapters, which proved to be more successful:

For left-handed users: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2443517
For right-handed users: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2692609

In December 2017 and January, 2018 I received a couple of requests asking for some improvements upon this design. So, now I'm updating it, with a couple of new features.

First of all, now you can choose from two different bases: One optimized for left-handed users and other one for right-handed users. The other parts of the assembly will work seamlessly with both of them.

I adjusted the dimensions for the Base.stl files. Now they can hold both Joy-Cons in a more efficient (and safe!) way. For extra security, I included a new part: JoyConBelt.stl, whose purpose is to act as a "lock" to prevent the Joy-Cons from slipping.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro 2016

No

Supports:

Yes

0.3mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

The use of honeycomb infill is strongly recommended to print the RightHandBase.stl and LeftHandBase.stl files successfully

print_settings.Notes:: With the old models the PLA was too brittle for the press-fit center hub, resulting in cracks. The new sandwich style model prints well in PLA as well as ABS now.

description.text:
I wanted to make a fidget spinner with a minimalistic design. This is what I came up with. This will fit a standard 8mm x 22mm x 7mm bearing, as found in inline skates.

This was designed using OpenSCAD.

Versions:
v2.4: Much improved reliability with a sandwich design (recommended for printing)
v1.1: Improved design with more reliable structure
v1.0: Initial upload.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

With the old models the PLA was too brittle for the press-fit center hub, resulting in cracks. The new sandwich style model prints well in PLA as well as ABS now.

After printing you can clean up the print if you want, but mostly it's ready to add the bearings.
You need three bearings this super simple spinner. Place the spinner on a hard flat surface and set a bearing level on the center hole. It should insert pretty easily, but be gentle and be sure to press it all the way in.
The two side bearings are slip onto the mounting posts easily. Before you add the top of the "sandwich, it is best to clean up the mounting holes and pegs a bit. Hold the top piece (with the pegs) at an offset angle so you can insert the pegs one at a time. Rotate each peg in its matching hole and put it in and out a few times so that it fits without being too tight.
Now you can add the top piece to complete the "sandwich".
Install the two beveled caps onto the center bearing. They should extend about 1mm past the spinner body, so you can set the spinner on a table and spin it.

Using Math in OpenSCAD

I included the OpenSCAD file I used to generate the STL file on this thing.

Many iterations; trial and error.

description.text:
Welcome to the Open-Belt™! This buckle is designed to work specifically with heavy duty work belts and gun belts. The unique design of the buckle takes up minimum space to allow for placement of holsters and other equipment around the belt with minimal interference. The buckle permits the belt to lay flat, which reduces the bulk at the buckle found on most heavy duty belts. The belt was specifically design to work very stiff materials like reinforced leather or a coated webbing called Biothane. These thick materials do not bend well so frequently create a bulge at the belt. This buckle allows a thick belt to pass right through the belt with no need for a bend at all.

The buckle is designed to work with standard flathead 8/32 screws and 1/8" screw posts. Buckle designed for a material with belt width of 1.435 in.

The buckle was 3d printed for testing initially with good success. We did have an occasional breakage of a 3D printed version in use but most worked for weeks without issue before being replaced with a newer version of the buckle. 3D printing may work for you if your usage is light and you use a high fill (>85%) ABS print with an acetone vapor treatment after. Milled aluminum, Nylon, or Delrin is recommended for long term use.

The full belt is available for purchase at https://www.blackarchholsters.com/collections/accessories/products/belt and we will make parts available at openballistics.com shortly.

Finishing

title: E3D Titan Mount for Prusa i3 Mk2-style X Carriage

description.text:
I've built yet another Prusa i3 clone, and I decided to use mostly the parts from the Original Prusa i3 Mk2 for my printed parts. Well, some parts needed modification, and since I wanted to use my MendelMax's E3D Titan instead of the stock extruder setup...

Description

This is designed to mount a ~2cm "pancake" stepper motor and E3D Titan extruder onto the Prusa i3 Mk2's X carriage. The X carriage I use started out life as the one available for the Original Prusa i3 Mk2. All I did was chop parts from the top and bottom that related to the stock extruder.

On my machine, this mount (with near-stock X ends and carriage for the Mk2) gives me a build height of ~190mm and full access to the 213x200mm glass plate that I print on.

Notes

The extruder motor mount can easily lose a millimeter on either side, to more snugly fit the motor. It works perfectly fine as-is though.

The hobbed gear for the extruder has approximately a millimeter between it and the mount. If your printer over-extrudes, you may need to file this a bit to let the gear turn freely.

Caveat emptor, as I don't actually own an Original Prusa i3 Mk2 to test this on.

title: 30mm fan cover with bowden stabilizer for Frankenstein Carriage

description.text: Part of my upgrade list for the Frankenstein E3D carriage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1692794). I run an E3D with a 1.75mm bowden. When the Anet A6 homes my carriage the bowden tube is bent at a rather sharp angle where it meets the hot end. So to help prolong the life of my bowden this fan cover comes with a guidance tube to help straighten the section of bowden that enters the hot end. I added some radiation flair to the whole thing because I have too much love for the Fallout series of video games.

title: Horse & Rider 3-layered-animal cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My youngest daughter just can't get enough horses. She kept nagging me about another horse carrying a rider as a companion for the rising horse.

When scaling the size should be referenced by the width of a foot.

This build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm beech plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.5 mm flute. After machining it needed a little sanding and simple gluing together. The bolts are for easy alignment only. Next time I try to keep the outer parts clean.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create (even) smaller versions. Probably you could make a aluminum or brass version and screw the parts together to get tiny key fob.

You can visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Toys/Animals for more animals.

remixed_from.author: jkoljo
remixed_from.title: i3ext for 1.75 mm E3D v5 hot end

description.text:
• This design is a derivative of my previous i3ext release, originally made by sgraber. It uses the same E3D compatible mounting rail, and adds an option to use a bowden fed second extruder.
  • The innovative part of this extuder is that it feeds the first extruder via a gear system, and the second with bowden. That allows very accurate prints using the first nozzle, and semiaccurate prints using the second nozzle, making it perfect for printing support material, and even a second color with a well tuned bowden system. It is a great tradeoff between carriage weight and accuracy.
  • The bowden part of the system is compatible with 1/8" standard pneufit, and 4 mm OD bowden tube. The hot ends will be 25 mm apart, a minimum distance for E3D hot end. There are two fan shrouds available, a thin version is needed if your X carriage comes in the way.
  • I have been testing the system for a few months now, and it works great! Here is a print made with the bowden fed extruder. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ef02mAOPs5s
  • The v3 extruder has reinforced back body, cleaner fan mount holes and a place for a short PTFE tube for direct extrusion side, making it much better for super flexible filaments!
  • The bowden extruder I am using:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26817
  • Original i3ext by sgraber:
    https://github.com/sgraber/i3ext

• Assemble direct drive section using the instructions in my previous i3ext mod (see sources)
  • Cut some bowden tube, and insert into the 4 mm hole under pneufit
  • Install pneufit
  • Install hot ends and fan shroud
  • To calibrate the nozzle heights, place pieces of paper behind the upper or lower linear bearings in the carriage

comments.text: I considered doing a single fan cooling for dual E3D's and was talked out of it. How have you found it works? Rumor was that it would cause PLA to jam in the heatbreak.
comments.author: mkelly

comments.text: The heatsinks are relatively cool while printing. I have since moved to liquid cooling, so I cannot make any measurements. I did not encounter any jams.
comments.author: mkelly

comments.text: would any modding be required for a v6?
comments.author: dinopuppy

comments.text: The upper geometry of v6 is identical to v5, so no modding is required.
comments.author: dinopuppy

comments.text:
Very nice design. I'm almost certainly going to use this for my Prusa i3. Just one question—What diameter of filament does it use? I have a bowden extruder that can use 3mm filament (which I use), but there does not seem to be much info on the geared, direct extruder. Can it use 3mm filament? Also, is the extruder compatable with bowden-fed 3mm filament?
Thanks!
comments.author: solomondg

comments.text: It is intended for 1,75 mm filament, sorry, 3 mm is not compatible at the moment.
comments.author: solomondg

comments.text: It seems that the OpenSCAD file has a variable for 3mm filament, and appears to make it comparable. Would that work, or are there other underlying problems with 3mm filament?
comments.author: jkoljo

comments.text: Yeah, it will work. You also have to modify PTFE tube diameter if you intend to use the dual extrusion feature.
comments.author: solomondg

comments.text: Dude. That's was exactly what I was looking for! I was planning to design myself but I will totally check your design first! Thanks for sharing!

Following additional materials are necessary for completing the project :

  • 1x 120 mm. fan
  • 4x M4x40
  • 2x M3x15
  • 2x M8x40
  • 2x M8 washers
  • 2x M8 wingnut
  • 1x on/off button (example) (I had this one laying around, the square indent in the mainbody is sized LxWxH 26x15x3).
  • 12V power supply (example) (I used a adjustable one to get different speeds)
  • 1x dust/carbon filter 3M type2135 or type 2138(unfortunately the outer layers of these filters have to be removed because of the high density. Might as well go for something else, and cut it to size)


Update 29-04-2017 16:27
Since I noticed the filter wanting to dent to the inside I made a filterguard to support the filter. Filename : "Solderfan120_Filterguard.stl". Also changed 2x M4x15 bolts in the BOM to 2x M3x15.

Update 30-04-2017 11:47
I've noticed that unfortunately the 3M filters don't do the job as intended. A lot of the fumes are bounced of because of the high density of the filters. But using the extractor with the complete filters still beats soldering without anything at all. I suggest cutting of the outer layers or use a different kind of material and cut it to size.
Also changed M4x50 bolts to M4x40. Allthough M4x50 will fit, I used M4x40.
And added a picture of the finished product.

comments.text: So where do you actually install the filter?
comments.author: marcbea

comments.text:
The last picture is a ring which will press-fit in the back of the body.
This will sandwich the filter inbetween an indent in the body (as far as i can remember, i left about 5 mm. for the thickness of the filter).
Ofcourse you will need to cut the filter to the size of the ring.
comments.author: marcbea

comments.text: ahh ok i'll probably use a activated charcoal filter instead. Well the body finished printing this morning so i will post some make pictures as soon as i have it assembled. Pretty big unit. Thinking this could be scaled down for 80mm too with the way its designed.
comments.author: Sjarcie

comments.text:
I do have to say (as also said in te description), High density filters bounce back the air, so i had to cut down on the layers of the actual filter used.
And yes, it should be possible to scale down to a 80mm fan size. If you want, i could have a look around to see if i can share the fusion360 files somewhere...

comments.text: Still going strong here at GV! I turned it into an Intro to the Engineering Design Cycle Challenge though. Looking at information on how it could be used to promote and raise money for Autism Awareness or reducing the amount of drugs prescribed each year that are ending up back in the water supply in trace amounts, just to name a few topics the kids have identified and started researching. Most of it is theoretical and they won't actually implement their proposals, but I figured it was better than "Ok, everyone design a fidget spinner." They get to design a team spinner that is tested on a device we made that allows them to mount the bearing to a skateboard truck and then drop an steel bar into the spinner. They record their times and some other info into a Google Form and then have to draw conclusions about the relationship between weight, radius, and time.  They use Adobe Sparkpage to present their findings. There's more to it, but that's the short version.

title: Fully Enclosed Car Interior Wire Holder

description.text:
After seeing other interior cable clips such as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1704844 I thought they were really great ideas, but none could deal with the odd height differences on the dash panels in my X-Type, nor the variety of cable widths for things such as an Aux lead, a sat nav USB cable and an iPhone cable, so I made these.

You simply insert the core of the cable up into the circle part of the clip, squeeze the legs together and shove it into the interior panel gap you have on the car.

There are 4 designs included,

Long Legs, Small Width - This has long legs that you shove into the panel gap, but a small cross section width for if the gap is quite deep, but not very wide.

Short Legs, Small Width - This has short legs that you shove into the panel gap, but a small cross section width for if the gap is shallow, but not very wide.

Long Legs, Large Width - This has long legs that you shove into the panel gap, but a small cross section width for if the gap is quite deep and the gap between the trim pieces is a little larger then usual.

Short Legs, Large Width - This has short legs that you shove into the panel gap, but a small cross section width for if the gap is fairly shallow and the gap between the trim pieces is a little larger then usual.

For most vehicles, you will probably want to use the ones that are "Small Width" with the choice of long or short legs up to you, depending how deep the legs need to go into the trim gap.

description.text: Ersatzteil für CD Hüllen

A simple program in OpenSCad to show how a circle can be created using sin and cos functions

This program simulates a circle by offsetting a cube in the x and y planes according to cos and sin functions respectively. It is designed to illustrate the effect of offsetting points according to trigonometric functions, in order to create 2-D objects. In this simulation, cos offset is shown in blue and sin is shown in red. Their combined offset is shown in purple.

The program is designed to be animated, with instructions in the sourcefile.

title: Winged Victory of Samothrace - Integrated Supports

description.text: The Cosmo Wenman scan of the Ancient greek statue was so fantastic that I wanted to make a high quality print, but I was afraid of the mess all the support material needed for the wings would make. After stumbling across a great tutorial on using MeshMixer to create integrated pillar supports (http://www.extrudable.me/2013/12/28/meshmixer-2-0-best-newcomer-in-a-supporting-role/), I decided to try it on this and it turned out GREAT! I was so happy with the result I decided to share it on Thingiverse. Hopefully it will allow others to print this fantastic model without all the hassle of cleaning off support material. Model has been scaled to fit the maximum print height of my modified solidoodle 3 (173mm). Cleanup after printing only took a few minutes! Unheard of for a print with this much of an overhang! Thanks to Cosmo for the great scan and I look forward to more of your models!

Print it without ANY supports turned on in your slicer. The example pictured here was printed at 0.2mm layer thickness in white ABS on a solidoodle 3 printer.   
I do recommend printing with a decent size brim (10mm pictured here) to make sure the support beams are secure on the bed.

comments.text: Thanks for this great addition to Cosmo's work.

description.text:
Your typical 24pin ATX power supply connector can provide many useful voltage levels to your other electronics projects.... ya got 3.3V, 5V, 12V and even -5V (has anyone ever used that one?)... anyways, it's great.

So, to leverage this handy connector, I bought a breakout board from ebay and found that all the through-hole solder pins on the bottom of this PCB were dangerously exposed to whatever highly conductive surface I'd care to callously toss it on. That won't do, so I made this nifty standoff (with 2.8mm holes that allow you to use the same screws as you'd find on a drive tray for mounting) and even added some tapered holes for wall/chassis/robot mounting.

Dimensions of the mount holes, centers to centers are:

69.5mm x 33mm

If you found this useful, it would bring me great joy to see your work - so be sure to share. :)

Also, feel free to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

A case for the well known (at least in Germany) Pollin LS-7.

This case is made of laser cut 3mm PMMA plates, although you can use any material that is 3mm thick. You will need some more parts:

  • 4 x M3 standoff 18mm
  • 4 x M3 standoff 15mm
  • 4 x 2mm high spacer with 3mm hole (I used 8 x nylon spacer 1mm high)
  • 4 x M3 14mm screws (DIN912/ISO4762)
  • 8 x M3 8mm screws (DIN912/ISO4762)
  • 4 x M3 6mm screws (DIN7991/ISO10642)
  • 2 x M2.5 3mm screws
  • DC jack for 11mm cut out

print_settings.Notes:: The LED holder bottom can be tricky to print because its at a weird angle. Make sure your slicer generates appropriate supports. I found the default in the Prusa Slic3r was being over-optimistic about how much overhang will work without supports, and had to adjust it to ensure the bottom lip is supported during printing.

title: Prusa I3 MK2 Pi Mount - Add-on LED Bar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an add-on part for my Raspberry Pi mount for the Prusa i3 MK2:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2267652

It adds another accessory bar under the mount (the first being the mount for the Pi Camera v2.1) that can be used to mount some high-output LEDs for illuminating the build platform.

The setup consists of a bottom and top of the "rod" that holds the LEDs. The top is meant to be printed with clear/transparent PLA or whatever appropriate clear material you have. The bottom, in my case, is printed black to match the printer. A flat panel with three 5mm holes mounts the LEDs with room for the wiring below them.

If you are using external power for your LEDs (connecting them to their own power source), you should print the mk-led-holder-bottom.stl version. This has room for wiring the LEDs and running power and ground to them. Any resistors or other controls would be associated with your power supply.

Alternately, if you're looking for powering the LEDs with the Pi, and controlling them via the Octoprint Enclosure plugin (so they turn on/off with printing), there's a second version with a small space behind the LEDs sufficient to hold the two resistors and transistor needed to safely power them. It also has a wider opening that will fit the three wires (power/ground/trigger) you need. A circuit diagram is included with the files. That said, the circuit is specific to the LEDs I used, so make sure you understand the resistor sizing and transistor requirements for the ones you use. Its a tight fit, but there's room for everything.

As with the camera mount, there are two nuts to secure the rod in place. (Although this one will self-center because the rod itself is wider.)

For my specific setup, I'm using three high-output Infrared LEDs from Adafruit (https://www.adafruit.com/product/387) because I have a No-IR Pi camera, and want to be able to record at night without the extra light. So they look very dim in the color photo above, but are screamin' bright in IR. I experimented with some white LEDs, and I believe that sufficient illumination would be provided by them, as well, for the standard camera.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The parts all have varying requirements for printing. You probably want to use a fairly low resolution for the "clear" cover for the LEDs -- it will be more transparent. That said, a higher resolution may give you a diffuser effect, so you may want to experiment.

The LED holder bottom can be tricky to print because its at a weird angle. Make sure your slicer generates appropriate supports. I found the default in the Prusa Slic3r was being over-optimistic about how much overhang will work without supports, and had to adjust it to ensure the bottom lip is supported during printing.

description.text: This piece is designed to hold a SparkFun Load Sensor - 50 kg (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10245?_ga=1.9476016.48925135.1486004091) in place while not obstructing the load sensor's effectiveness. This is accomplished by holding the sensor off the ground while not interfering with any downward force. To use this design, two pieces must be printed. Sandwich the load sensor in between the sensors and use bolts or screws to hold the pieces together. This will prevent any movement of the load sensor and can be attached to any wooden surface.

title: Makergear M2 60mm Bed Fan for V4 Hot End

description.text: I replaced the stock 50mm Bed fan with a 60mm Noctua (NF-A6x25) - slightly higher airflow, 1/3 of the noise - this did require using a buck converter to convert the power to 12v rather than the 24v that was used for the stock fan. I had previously been using a funnel designed for the stock fan with a 50mm to 60mm converter attached to it, but wanted a better solution for my fan mount. I modified the Filament Feed from the Makergear GitHub site with an arm and built a new funnel which provided better airflow than the previous setup. I built this in 2 parts so that it could be adapted for various other fans if anyone choose to do so, also it helps improve the print. I have tested several prints with this setup and it works wonderfully and reduces the noise level even further due to not being held on by a single bolt through the extruder fan which created a lot of vibration noise.

Printer Brand:

For the filament feed - use a 2mm drill bit to open up the feed path through the part.

title: Amonkhet-themed Obelisk Deck Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
In honor of Magic: The Gathering's Amonkhet block, I made a themed deck box.

It's a fairly straightforward obelisk, with simplified Bolas horns on the top and the names of the five gods inscribed on three sides. The fourth side holds a life counter.

It will hold up to a 100 card, single-sleeved EDH deck. I'll probably include a custom spacer as well in a bit so it holds a 60 card deck nice and snug, as well as a sideboard.

I tried some fancier mechanisms and couldn't get it to work, so I settled for opening it simply by sliding off the capstone. It should snap in place fairly well, so you can throw it in a bag and not worry about it opening up. Although obviously the horns are a weak point.

7/01/2017

I've added a variant of the obelisk portion that does not have the names of the gods.
